title: Isaiah Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 8.

questions.question: What was Isaiah instructed to take and write with a man's pen?
questions.correctAnswer: A great roll
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:1 states the LORD said to take a great roll and write in it with a man's pen.

questions.question: Who were the two faithful witnesses that Isaiah took with him?
options: Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah
questions.correctAnswer: Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:2 names Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah as the faithful witnesses.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 8:3, what was the name given to the son born to the prophetess?
questions.correctAnswer: Mahershalalhashbaz
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:3 states the LORD told Isaiah to name the son Mahershalalhashbaz.

questions.question: Before the child Mahershalalhashbaz can say 'My father, and my mother,' what will happen?
options: The riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken by the king of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: The riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken by the king of Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:4 foretells that before the child can speak, the riches and spoil will be taken away.

questions.question: What do the people refuse according to Isaiah 8:6?
options: The waters of Shiloah that go softly
questions.correctAnswer: The waters of Shiloah that go softly
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:6 says the people refuse the waters of Shiloah that go softly.

questions.question: Who is described as bringing up the waters of the river, strong and many?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:7 says the Lord brings up the king of Assyria with strong and many waters.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 8:8, to what extent will the king of Assyria pass through Judah?
options: He shall reach even to the neck
He shall only enter the borders
He will not pass through Judah
He will pass but not stay
questions.correctAnswer: He shall reach even to the neck
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:8 states the king of Assyria will overflow and go over, reaching even to the neck.

questions.question: What is the name mentioned in Isaiah 8:8 that refers to the land?
questions.correctAnswer: Immanuel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:8 calls the land 'O Immanuel,' indicating 'God with us.'

questions.question: What does Isaiah 8:10 say about taking counsel and speaking the word?
options: They shall come to nought and not stand
They shall prosper and be heard
questions.correctAnswer: They shall come to nought and not stand
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:10 explains that counsel and words will fail because God is with us.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 8:12 commands people to say 'A confederacy' to those who say it and to fear their fear.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:12 instructs not to say 'A confederacy' or fear their fear.

questions.question: Who should be sanctified and feared according to Isaiah 8:13?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:13 says to sanctify the LORD of hosts and let Him be your fear and dread.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 8:14 describes the LORD as a sanctuary and a stone of stumbling to the houses of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:14 states God will be a sanctuary and also a stone of stumbling and rock of offence.

questions.question: What is Isaiah told to do with the testimony and law in Isaiah 8:16?
options: Bind up the testimony and seal the law among his disciples
questions.correctAnswer: Bind up the testimony and seal the law among his disciples
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:16 directs Isaiah to bind up and seal the testimony and law among his disciples.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Behold, I and the children whom the LORD hath given me are for ______ and for wonders in Israel.'
questions.correctAnswer: signs
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:18 says Isaiah and his children are for signs and wonders in Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 8:19 encourages people to seek guidance from those who have familiar spirits and wizards.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:19 questions why people would seek the dead instead of their God.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to trust God during difficult times. Based on Isaiah 8, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God?
options: God is with us and His counsel will not fail
We should rely on human alliances for security
Fear is the only proper response to trials
God hides His face and is indifferent to our plight
questions.correctAnswer: God is with us and His counsel will not fail
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:10 teaches that taking counsel together will come to nought but emphasizes that God is with us. This encourages trust in God's presence and plan despite adversity. Also, Isaiah 8:11-12 warns not to fear like the people, but to sanctify the LORD and fear Him alone.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 8 describe the role of God's signs and wonders in family life and parenting?
options: Children given by God serve as signs and wonders in Israel
Children are to be disciplined harshly to prevent stumbling
Parents should hide their children from public view
Children are irrelevant to spiritual testimony
questions.correctAnswer: Children given by God serve as signs and wonders in Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:18 states that the prophet and the children God has given him are for signs and wonders in Israel. This shows the importance of family as a testimony of God's work and presence, teaching us to view children as God’s gifts and witnesses of faith.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to seek guidance from sources other than God. According to Isaiah 8, what should they do?
options: Seek unto the law and the testimony of God
Consult wizards and familiar spirits for answers
Rely solely on their own understanding
questions.correctAnswer: Seek unto the law and the testimony of God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:19-20 instructs believers not to seek guidance from familiar spirits or wizards but to rely on the law and testimony. This teaches us to depend on God's Word as the true source of spiritual light and guidance.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 8 suggest about obedience and walking in God’s ways amidst a disobedient people?
options: Do not walk in the way of this people; sanctify the LORD and fear Him
Follow the majority to avoid conflict
Compromise your faith to fit in
questions.correctAnswer: Do not walk in the way of this people; sanctify the LORD and fear Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:11-13 commands not to follow the ways of the people who refuse God but to sanctify the LORD and fear Him. This emphasizes personal obedience and reverence for God despite societal pressure.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach us about perseverance during trials and waiting on the Lord?
options: Wait upon the LORD who hides His face, trusting in Him
Give up when God seems distant
Act hastily without seeking God’s will
questions.correctAnswer: Wait upon the LORD who hides His face, trusting in Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:17 encourages waiting on the LORD even when He hides His face, showing perseverance and faith in God's timing. This teaches us to patiently trust God in trials.

questions.question: A believer is feeling discouraged because of difficulties. What does Isaiah 8 say about God being a sanctuary and a stumbling stone?
options: God is a sanctuary for those who trust Him but a stone of offense for the disobedient
God always rewards immediately and never causes stumbling
God is indifferent to human struggles
God’s presence removes all challenges instantly
questions.correctAnswer: God is a sanctuary for those who trust Him but a stone of offense for the disobedient
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:14 explains that God is a sanctuary to some but a stone of stumbling to others, indicating that faith brings safety while rejection of God leads to offense and difficulty. This teaches believers about the dual nature of God's presence.

questions.question: How can Isaiah 8 encourage believers to maintain integrity and trust in God rather than human alliances?
options: The people are warned against rejoicing in Rezin and Remaliah’s son, symbolizing reliance on human allies
The chapter encourages making many political alliances
Human alliances guarantee safety without God
Trusting others is more important than trusting God
questions.correctAnswer: The people are warned against rejoicing in Rezin and Remaliah’s son, symbolizing reliance on human allies
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:6-7 warns that the people reject the gentle waters of Shiloah (God’s provision) and instead rejoice in political alliances (Rezin and Remaliah’s son), which leads to destruction. This teaches reliance on God’s protection over human alliances.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 8 teach about the importance of recording and preserving God’s testimony?
options: Bind up the testimony and seal the law among disciples
Forget the law and focus on personal opinion
Only rely on memory without writing down God’s word
questions.correctAnswer: Bind up the testimony and seal the law among disciples
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:16 instructs to bind up the testimony and seal the law among the prophet’s disciples, highlighting the importance of preserving and passing on God’s word faithfully for instruction and obedience.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 8 emphasizes that fear of man and their threats should guide a believer’s actions.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:12-13 commands believers not to say 'a confederacy' in fear of others, but to sanctify the LORD and fear Him instead. This shows that fear of man should not control a believer’s actions.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 8, God’s presence assures believers that all human plans will succeed.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:10 states that human counsel and words will come to nought, but God is with us. This means human plans may fail, but God’s presence is the true assurance, not success in human schemes.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 8:4 says before the child knows to cry 'My father, and my mother,' the riches of ______ and the spoil of Samaria will be taken.
questions.correctAnswer: Damascus
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:4 states the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria shall be taken before the child knows to cry 'My father, and my mother,' emphasizing the swift fulfillment of God’s judgment.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 8 instruct believers to respond when facing spiritual deception and false guidance?
options: Seek the law and testimony of God for true light
Follow wizards and familiar spirits for answers
questions.correctAnswer: Seek the law and testimony of God for true light
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:19-20 warns against seeking guidance from familiar spirits and instead directs people to the law and testimony, the true source of light and right guidance.

questions.question: Isaiah 8:8 speaks of the king of Assyria as a flood that will overflow and reach even to the neck. How can this imagery teach us about the trials believers may face?
options: Trials can be overwhelming but God’s presence (Immanuel) remains amidst them
Believers will never face overwhelming trials
Flood imagery means abandonment by God
questions.correctAnswer: Trials can be overwhelming but God’s presence (Immanuel) remains amidst them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:8 mentions the flood reaching to the neck and filling the land of Immanuel, symbolizing overwhelming trials but the presence of God (Immanuel) remains. This teaches perseverance and trust in God during hardships.

questions.question: What practical lesson does Isaiah 8 offer about dealing with fear in Christian life?
options: Sanctify the LORD and let Him be your fear, not the fear of men
Fear all people equally and avoid confrontation
Ignore fear completely and act recklessly
questions.correctAnswer: Sanctify the LORD and let Him be your fear, not the fear of men
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:13 teaches to sanctify the LORD and let Him be your fear and dread, rather than fearing men. This encourages reverent fear of God, which leads to obedience and peace.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 8, how should a believer respond when feeling hungry or spiritually empty under trials?
options: Continue to trust God rather than cursing Him or the king
Give up and curse God for the hardship
Turn away from God to find earthly comfort
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to trust God rather than cursing Him or the king
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:21 describes people who, when hungry, fret and curse their king and God, looking upward. The chapter implicitly warns against this response, teaching believers to maintain faith and trust even in spiritual hunger.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 8.

questions.question: What was Isaiah commanded to write on a great roll concerning?
questions.correctAnswer: Mahershalalhashbaz
questions.explanation: Isaiah was told by the LORD to take a great roll and write with a man's pen concerning Mahershalalhashbaz (Isaiah 8:1).

questions.question: Who were the two faithful witnesses Isaiah took to record what was written?
options: Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah
questions.correctAnswer: Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah
questions.explanation: Isaiah took Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah as faithful witnesses to record (Isaiah 8:2).

questions.question: What name did the LORD command Isaiah to call the son born to the prophetess?
questions.correctAnswer: Mahershalalhashbaz
questions.explanation: The LORD told Isaiah to name the son born to the prophetess Mahershalalhashbaz (Isaiah 8:3).

questions.question: Before the child Mahershalalhashbaz can say 'My father' or 'My mother,' what will happen?
options: The riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken by the king of Assyria
The king of Assyria will be defeated
The people will turn to God
questions.correctAnswer: The riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken by the king of Assyria
questions.explanation: Before the child can say 'My father' or 'My mother,' the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken by the king of Assyria (Isaiah 8:4).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'waters of Shiloah that go softly' in this chapter?
options: They represent a peaceful trust in God rejected by the people
They symbolize the power of the king of Assyria
They are the waters that flood Judah
They refer to the rivers of Damascus
questions.correctAnswer: They represent a peaceful trust in God rejected by the people
questions.explanation: The people refused the waters of Shiloah that go softly, symbolizing their rejection of God's peaceful provision and instead rejoicing in foreign alliances (Isaiah 8:6).

questions.question: The invasion described as 'the waters of the river, strong and many' refers to which historical figure?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Assyria
questions.explanation: The 'waters of the river, strong and many' metaphorically describe the king of Assyria and his overwhelming invasion (Isaiah 8:7).

questions.question: What does the name 'Immanuel' signify in the context of Isaiah 8:8?
questions.correctAnswer: God with us
questions.explanation: 'Immanuel' means 'God with us,' indicating God's presence even amid the Assyrian invasion (Isaiah 8:8).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 8:10, what is the outcome of counsels taken without God's presence?
options: They will come to nothing and fail
They will succeed in defeating Assyria
They will bring peace and prosperity
They will cause the people to rejoice
questions.correctAnswer: They will come to nothing and fail
questions.explanation: Isaiah declares that counsels and words without God’s presence will come to nought and not stand (Isaiah 8:10).

questions.question: What does Isaiah instruct not to say in response to the people's fear, as per Isaiah 8:12?
options: Fear not, for God is with us
Blessed is the man who trusts in the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Say not, A confederacy
questions.explanation: Isaiah commands not to say 'A confederacy' to those who say it and not to fear their fear (Isaiah 8:12).

questions.question: In Isaiah 8:13, what are believers instructed to sanctify as their fear and dread?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Believers are told to sanctify the LORD of hosts himself and let Him be their fear and dread (Isaiah 8:13).

questions.question: Isaiah 8:14 describes the LORD as a sanctuary and also as what to the houses of Israel?
options: A stone of stumbling and a rock of offence
questions.correctAnswer: A stone of stumbling and a rock of offence
questions.explanation: The LORD will be a sanctuary but also a stone of stumbling and rock of offence to Israel (Isaiah 8:14).

questions.question: What action does Isaiah take regarding the testimony and the law among his disciples as stated in Isaiah 8:16?
options: He binds up the testimony and seals the law
He proclaims the law loudly in the streets
He hides the law from the people
questions.correctAnswer: He binds up the testimony and seals the law
questions.explanation: Isaiah binds up the testimony and seals the law among his disciples (Isaiah 8:16).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 8:18, what role do Isaiah and his children serve in Israel?
options: Signs and wonders from the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Signs and wonders from the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah and his children are for signs and wonders in Israel from the LORD of hosts (Isaiah 8:18).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 8:19 warn against seeking for guidance?
questions.correctAnswer: Familiar spirits and wizards
questions.explanation: Isaiah warns not to seek those who have familiar spirits and wizards but to seek the living God (Isaiah 8:19).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 8:20 teaches that any word not according to the law and testimony has no light in it.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah teaches that if people do not speak according to the law and the testimony, there is no light in them (Isaiah 8:20).

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What name was Isaiah instructed by the LORD to write on a great roll concerning the prophecy?
questions.correctAnswer: Mahershalalhashbaz
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:1 commands writing the name Mahershalalhashbaz on a great roll. This name symbolizes the swift spoil of Damascus and Samaria, highlighting God's sovereign judgment (Isaiah 7:3; Jeremiah 28:10; Luke 1:31; Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: Who were the two faithful witnesses Isaiah took to record the prophecy?
options: Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah
questions.correctAnswer: Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:2 identifies Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah as faithful witnesses, underscoring the importance of credible testimony in divine revelation (Deuteronomy 19:15; Matthew 18:16; 2 Corinthians 13:1; Revelation 11:3).

questions.question: What was the significance of the child born to the prophetess, as described in Isaiah 8?
options: He was named Mahershalalhashbaz and symbolized imminent judgment
He was named Immanuel and symbolized God's presence
He was a king of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He was named Mahershalalhashbaz and symbolized imminent judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:3-4 reveals the child named Mahershalalhashbaz as a prophetic sign of the swift capture of Damascus and Samaria, symbolizing God's impending judgment (Isaiah 7:14; Jeremiah 1:11-12; Hosea 1:4; Luke 2:21).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 8, what will happen before the child can say 'My father' or 'My mother'?
options: The riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken by the king of Assyria
The temple in Jerusalem will be destroyed
Israel will be delivered from all enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken by the king of Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:4 prophesies that before the child's knowledge to speak, Damascus and Samaria will be plundered by Assyria, illustrating God's sovereign control over history and judgment (Jeremiah 46:2; 2 Kings 16:9; Habakkuk 1:5; Romans 9:17).

questions.question: What does the 'waters of Shiloah that go softly' symbolize in Isaiah 8?
options: God’s gentle and faithful provision and protection
questions.correctAnswer: God’s gentle and faithful provision and protection
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:6 uses the waters of Shiloah to symbolize God's gentle sustaining presence, which the people reject in favor of foreign alliances, highlighting the futility of trusting man over God (Psalm 23:2; John 7:38; Ezekiel 47:1-12; Revelation 22:1-2).

questions.question: Who is the 'king of Assyria' described as in Isaiah 8:7-8?
options: A flood of powerful waters symbolizing overwhelming judgment
questions.correctAnswer: A flood of powerful waters symbolizing overwhelming judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:7-8 depicts the king of Assyria as a flood overflowing banks, representing God's instrument of judgment against Israel’s rebellion (Nahum 1:8; Ezekiel 32:2; Habakkuk 1:6; Revelation 16:12).

questions.question: What is the significance of the name 'Immanuel' in Isaiah 8:8?
options: It means 'God with us,' signifying God’s presence even amid judgment
It means 'The Conqueror,' referring to Assyria
It is the name of a false prophet
It signifies the destruction of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It means 'God with us,' signifying God’s presence even amid judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:8 refers to the land of Immanuel, meaning 'God with us,' emphasizing God’s abiding presence despite the coming invasion, a messianic theme fulfilled in Christ (Isaiah 7:14; Matthew 1:23; John 1:14; Hebrews 13:5).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 8:10, what will happen to the plans and words of those who oppose God?
options: They will come to nothing and not stand, for God is with us
They will be judged by human courts
questions.correctAnswer: They will come to nothing and not stand, for God is with us
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:10 affirms that despite human schemes, God's presence ensures their failure, reflecting God’s sovereign protection (Psalm 33:10-11; Proverbs 19:21; Matthew 21:42; Romans 8:31).

questions.question: What instruction did the LORD give Isaiah regarding how he should not behave, according to Isaiah 8:11?
options: Not to walk in the way of the people who reject God
questions.correctAnswer: Not to walk in the way of the people who reject God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:11 records God instructing Isaiah to avoid following the rebellious ways of the people, illustrating the call to holiness and separation from sin (Psalm 1:1; Romans 12:2; 1 Peter 1:15-16; Ephesians 4:17-19).

questions.question: What command does Isaiah give concerning fear in Isaiah 8:12-13?
options: Do not fear the fears of others but sanctify the LORD of hosts as your fear
Fear the Assyrian king above all
Fear no one and trust in yourself
questions.correctAnswer: Do not fear the fears of others but sanctify the LORD of hosts as your fear
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:12-13 teaches to reject human fear and elevate reverence and awe for God alone, emphasizing the attribute of God as the fearful and holy one (Deuteronomy 6:13; Proverbs 9:10; Hebrews 12:28-29; 1 John 4:18).

questions.question: In Isaiah 8:14, how is the LORD described in relation to Israel and Jerusalem?
options: A sanctuary to some but a stone of stumbling and rock of offense to others
questions.correctAnswer: A sanctuary to some but a stone of stumbling and rock of offense to others
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:14 describes God as both refuge and offense, a theme echoed in Christ who is a cornerstone rejected by some (Psalm 118:22; Romans 9:33; 1 Peter 2:7-8; John 10:30-33).

questions.question: What is the significance of 'binding up the testimony and sealing the law among disciples' in Isaiah 8:16?
options: Preserving and safeguarding God's revelation for faithful followers
Concealing the law from the people
questions.correctAnswer: Preserving and safeguarding God's revelation for faithful followers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:16 emphasizes the responsibility to preserve the prophetic word securely among disciples, paralleling New Testament emphasis on guarding the gospel (Deuteronomy 31:24-26; 2 Timothy 1:13-14; Jude 1:3; Revelation 22:10).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 8:18, who are described as signs and wonders in Israel?
options: Isaiah and the children given to him by the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah and the children given to him by the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:18 states that Isaiah and his children serve as divine signs and wonders, indicating God’s ongoing revelation and messianic foreshadowing (Genesis 17:19; Matthew 1:21; Luke 2:25-32; Acts 2:17-18).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 8:19 warn against seeking when people ask for guidance?
options: Those who have familiar spirits and wizards instead of seeking God
questions.correctAnswer: Those who have familiar spirits and wizards instead of seeking God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:19 warns against consulting mediums and spiritists, urging reliance on God alone for guidance, consistent with Old Testament prohibitions (Leviticus 19:31; Deuteronomy 18:10-12; Galatians 5:19-21; 1 Corinthians 10:20).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 8:20, what standard must all teachings conform to?
questions.correctAnswer: The law and the testimony
questions.explanation: Isaiah 8:20 instructs that teachings must align with God's law and testimony—Scripture—as the definitive standard, affirming sola scriptura principles (Deuteronomy 17:19; Psalm 119:105; 2 Timothy 3:16-17; John 17:17).
